column23: AIM; Cabo Ligado; Integrity Magazine; Radio Mozambique; Zitamar
column25: On 28 September 2024, the Mozambican president inaugurated barracks of the UIR in the district of Metuge (location coded to Metuge, Metuge, Cabo Delgado), calling UIR officers to fight Islamist militia insurgency in the Northern province of Cabo Delgado. The headquarters consists of three barracks, eight residences for officers, four for generals, and other facilities, including a shooting range. The provincial headquarters occupy an area of around 160 hectares, the largest barracks built since Mozambican independence in 1975.

column23: Cabo Ligado; Televisao de Mozambique; Zumbo FM
column25: On 28 September 2024, Islamist militia kidnapped five women working in crop fields outside Chinda (Mocimboa da Praia, Cabo Delgado). The Islamist militia ransomed them for food and the women gave them potatoes, cassava, and tomatoes. The militia released the women after they gave them food. The district administrator of Mocimboa da Praia claimed the militia asked the women if they would be given amnesty if they surrendered.

Around 26 September 2024 (as reported), residents barricaded access to the neighborhood office with burning logs in Chiboene in the district of Moamba (location coded to Moamba, Moamba, Maputo) to demonstrate over claims of delay in the electrification of the neighborhood.

column23: AIM; Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Centro de Integridade Publica (CIP); Integrity Magazine; Telegram; Televisao de Mozambique
column25: On 26 September 2024, a group of ten Islamist militia abducted a man heading to crop fields in Naliandele about 7km from Palma (Palma, Cabo Delgado), and killed him. The man was searching for food with his wife, who was released. Some residents tried to leave their houses but were sent back by Rwandan military forces. The Islamist militia was heading towards the Nhica do Rovuma region, looking for food and supplies in the surrounding communities. The Islamic State claimed the killing of a 'Christian' in Mangona.

column23: Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Telegram
column25: On 26 September 2024, for a third consecutive day, Islamist militia clashed with Mozambican and Rwandan military forces in Mucojo (Macomia, Cabo Delgado). The Islamic State claimed the clashes, killing and injuring an unknown number of soldiers. Unspecified fatalities coded as 3. Some soldiers fled the area and some Islamist militia were forced into the forests of the district of Quissanga.

Around 25 September 2024 (as reported), at least 182 Islamist militia handed themselves to Mozambican authorities and were reintegrated into their communities, and an unknown number of people who were abducted by the militia also returned to their families (location coded to Pemba, Pemba, Cabo Delgado), according to the president of Mozambique during the ceremony commemorating the 60th anniversary of the Outbreak of Mozambican military forces.

column23: Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Lusa; Noticias; Televisao de Mozambique; Zitamar; Zumbo FM
column25: On 25 September 2024, for a second consecutive day, Islamist militia clashed with Mozambican and Rwandan military forces outside Mucojo (Macomia, Cabo Delgado), according to the president of Mozambique during the ceremony commemorating the 60th anniversary of the Outbreak of Mozambican military forces. At least ten Islamist militia and four soldiers were killed (disputing reports, ranging between four and 12 soldiers killed, and eight injured), and the Mozambican military forces captured four Islamist militia according to the Chief of Staff of the Northern Operational Command. Military vehicles headed toward Mucojo. The Islamic State claimed injuring an unknown number of Mozambican and Rwandan soldiers.

Operators also claimed they have been complaining about the protectionism promoted in favor of a vessel since 2019 but without any response.

Movement of forces: Around 23 September 2024 (as reported), Islamist militants were seen in Mocimboa Da Praia (Mocimboa da Praia, Cabo Delgado). The city's mayor announced a traffic restriction from midnight to maintain vigilance. The movement was likely due to recent offensives from Rwandan and Mozambican military against Islamist militia in the forests of Mucojo about 100km from Mocimboa da Praia.

column23: AIM; Carta de Mocambique; Centro de Integridade Publica (CIP)
column25: On 23 September 2024, a mob set fire to a PODEMOS pickup truck carrying sound equipment in Mabote (Inhambane, Inhambane), to be used in a march and rally led by PODEMOS. The truck was parked very close to where the PODEMOS supporters were staying. The incident happened in the context of the upcoming October 2024 general elections.

On 23 September 2024, residents from Mahubo neighborhood in Boane blocked a road (means unspecified) for about four hours in Boane (Boane, Maputo) to protest against a water shortage and lack of electricity. Police officers intervened firing shots and using dogs, and removed the roadblocks. The officers detained a young man who was leading the march for some hours and later released him. The officers tore his shirt and he had bruises on his arm.

On 23 September 2024, residents from Gimo O'Cossa neighborhood in Bobole and blocks 10, 11, and 12 in Maluana barricaded the gate to the Electricity of Mozambique (EDM) headquarters with burning logs and blocked by (unspecified means) several areas of the road EN1 in Maputo (Maputo City, Maputo) while demonstrating against alleged delays in electrification. Police forces were present at EDM headquarters (no interaction was reported).

Around 20 September 2024 (as reported), Mozambican and Rwandan military forces reoccupied Pangane (Macomia, Cabo Delgado), according to the governor of the province of Cabo Delgado. No clashes reported. The joint offensive began in August by land and air, with Rwandan and Mozambican forces moving from the coast westwards.

Around 20 September 2024 (as reported), residents set fire to the bar of a man in Pambarra (Vilankulo, Inhambane) accused of leading a group of human organ traffickers and abducting and killing a man who was drinking at his bar and was later found without his genitals and one of his legs in the region, after disappearing for one month. Residents also barricaded National Highway Number 1 in the village on 19 September (coded separately).

Around 19 September 2024 (as reported), Mozambican military forces started the construction of a military base between the towns of Macomia and Quissanga (Quissanga, Cabo Delgado). Quissanga was occupied by Islamist militia in March and Macomia was briefly occupied in May.

On 19 September 2024, locals barricaded the National Highway Number 1 with tires on fire and tree trunks in Pambarra (Vilankulo, Inhambane), demanding the expulsion of a bar owner accused of killing a man to sell his organs from their community. The road was barricaded for more than three hours. Residents also stoned the car of a group of people accused of being human organ traffickers led by the bar owner and removed four children from the car, suspected of being kidnapped by the group. The vehicle fled. The incident happened during the funeral of the victim, who was abducted while drinking at the perpetrator's bar and was later found without his genitals and one of his legs in the region, after disappearing for one month.

Students complained about lack of communication and alleged imposition of contracts to access the integrated internships, accusing the institution's management of acting outside the law.

On 13 September 2024, police officers tortured a prisoner with a blunt object in the cell of a police station in Beira (Cidade Da Beira, Sofala), and killed him. The man was accused of being part of a gang indicted for aggravated robbery. The man was killed five days after being detained, with signs of aggression. The police claimed the man was detained in a weakened state of health, but the death certificate suggested trauma with a blunt force and boiling liquid, which caused injuries to various parts of the victim, especially his back and legs. His body also had two-degree burns.

column23: AIM; Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Centro de Integridade Publica (CIP); VOA
column25: On 5 September 2024, an unidentified armed group killed seven fishers in Mocimboa da Praia (Mocimboa Da Praia, Cabo Delgado). Malinde and Cabaceira residents found the bodies along the coast of the village, three in Cabeceira and one in Malinde. One person was beheaded. All victims were blindfolded and had their hands tied. It is suspected that the victims were tied up and then thrown into the sea where they drowned. Conflicting reports claimed Islamic Militia were responsible for the attack, while the Mozambican military forces were accused by locals of extorting, tying up, and beating civilians who tried to cross the Anga bridge on the south side of Mocimboa da Praia.

The incident happened in the context of the upcoming October 2024 general election.

column25: On 2 September 2024, an unidentified group vandalized the house backyard and the door house of a TV Sucesso journalist in Pemba (Pemba, Cabo Delgado) while he was away, following the publication of a report by the journalist about a police ban on a picnic organized by supporters of PODEMOS' presidential candidate. The journalist claimed that unknown people also parked outside his house on 31 August, at dawn, and called him, threatening him. The man was at home and saw the vehicle. The journalist claimed one of the members of the group was hired by one of his brothers to kill him over a dispute over a house left by his father. The journalist has been receiving threatening calls and messages from unknown individuals since the start of the election campaign on August 24. The incident happened in the context of the upcoming October 2024 general election.

column8: EUMAM: European Union Military Advisory mission in Mozambique (2024-)
column25: Other: On 1 September 2024, the EU Training Mission in Mozambique (EUTM) transitioned to the EU Military Assistance Mission (EUMAM) (location coded to Pemba, Pemba, Cabo Delgado), based on the EUTM and following the EU's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). EUTM trained 11 units of marines and commandos. EUTM trained more than 1,7000 Mozambican military forces. EUMAM aims to provide comprehensive military training and advisory support to the Mozambican military forces, helping the forces achieve a sustainable operational cycle by June 2026. The main EUTM actions that EUMAN will continue include enhancing the counter-terrorism capacity of Mozambican military forces, supporting civilian protection, and promoting human rights and compliance with international humanitarian law. EUMAN is formed by a staff of 83 people from Portugal, Italy, Spain, Romania, Lithuania, Belgium, Austria, Finland, Estonia, Greece, France, and non-EU country Serbia.

column23: AIM; Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Deutsche Welle; Mozambique Bulletin Subscribe; O Pais; Telegram; VOA; Zitamar
column25: On 31 August 2024, a group of about 10 armed Islamist militia ambushed Rwandan military forces in Mota neighborhood in Mocimboa Da Praia (Mocimboa da Praia, Cabo Delgado) and fired shots at 1 de Maio and Budji neighborhoods. A 16-year-old girl was killed in an exchange of fire, hit by a stray bullet. Islamist militia fled the area. Blood was found on the ground of Mota neighborhood. Before the ambush, the Islamist militia entered a house and asked for water. The Islamic State claimed attacking Rwandan forces, killing at least 1 Rwandan and injuring an unknown number of soldiers.

column23: AIM; Carta de Mocambique; Integrity Magazine; Miramar; O Pais; Twitter
column25: Other: On 18 August 2024, a police officer in civilian clothes tried to kill the CAD's presidential candidate claimed that a police officer in civilian clothes tried to kill him Quissico (Zavala, Inhambane) during a CAD's pre-campaign march led by him for the Presidential Election. The police officer got behind the Presidential Candidate's security line and pushed and kicked a provincial police officer who was protecting the candidate. The officer tried to force his way through the security barrier to get close to the candidate but a security guard restrained the officer, who was carrying a gun with 15 bullets. The security team seized the weapon. The police officer was detained. Local police denied the assassination attempt and claimed the officer was on duty at the location to protect the march.

Around 15 August 2024 (month of), Rwandan and Mozambican military forces reoccupied Mucojo (Macomia, Cabo Delgado), according to the governor of the province of Cabo Delgado. Casualties unknown. column23: AIM; BBC News; Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Lusa; VOA; Zitamar; Zumbo FM
column25: On 9 August 2024, Islamist militia using at least one motorboat (disputing reports ranging between 1 and 2) kidnapped between 60 to 74 fishermen who were fishing in the island Ntembuzi off the coast of Mocimboa da Praia (Mocimboa da Praia, Cabo Delgado). The Islamist militia seized three trawlers and demanded a ransom of $2,900 for the release of the fishermen. No ramson was paid. The militia took them to Quiterajo and released them unharmed, without a clear explanation, after three days in captivity. Mozambican authorities negotiated with the militia to release the fishermen. A fisherman claimed he recognized some militia as acquaintances and relatives from Mocimboa da Praia and as Tanzanians.

column25: Other: On 4 July 2024, the Mozambican Ministry of National Defense announced the closure of the SAMIM - SADC's Mission in Mozambique during a ceremony in Pemba (Pemba, Cabo Delgado). The mission started in July 2021 to combat Islamist militia attacks in Cabo Delgado. The mission commander handed weapons seized from Islamist militia during the closure ceremony, including 8 RPG-7 and PKM, 1 machine gun, 1 mortar, 70 AK-47s, 7 pistols and 1 AKS/SAR, G3 RIFLE, rockets, ammunition, and cartridges, as well as Islam books.

column23: AIM; Carta de Mocambique; Lusa; Miramar; O Pais; Televisao de Mozambique; Twitter; VOA
column25: On 4 June 2024, about 300 former SENASP officers camped in protest outside the UNDP headquarters in Maputo (Maputo City, Maputo) to claim financial compensation linked to the General Peace Agreement overdue for 20 years. More than 50 Rapid Intervention Unit members and police officers intervened with 15 police vehicles, dogs, and shots. Police officers detained an activist and journalist from the Center for Democracy and Human Rights, and physically assaulted two STV journalists, seizing a TV camera (disputing reports if the camera was seized by police officers or by an unidentified group). Extent of injuries unknown/not reported. Officers pushed the Center for Democracy's journalist into the back of a police vehicle and she was injured in the head. She was released on the following day. Police officers also forced other protesters to get into police cars against their will. The group started the demonstration around 27 May (coded separately). The stolen camera contained images of violence perpetrated by the officers.

column25: On 10 May 2024, at least 100 Islamist militia, including dozens of child soldiers, coming from at least three directions, clashed with Mozambican and South African military forces (part of SAMIM), local forces (coded as Macomia Communal Militia), and RIU officers in Macomia (Macomia, Cabo Delgado) and occupied the town. At least 10 people were killed (fatalities ranging between 10 and 23), including a local force commander, 4 soldiers and 4 RIU officers. The Mozambican Ministry of National Defense claimed one of the Islamist militia leaders was wounded and escaped, and another was killed. 4 bodies were found at a bridge over the Nanga River (no further details). Residents claimed they found the bodies of 2 leaders of the militia. Four civilians were hit by bullets (extent of injuries not reported/unknown). Over 700 people fled the area between 10 and 12 May (coded separately). An unknown number of International Red Cross staff members are suspected of having been kidnapped. Islamist militia looted shops owned by foreign nationals, mainly Bangladeshis, and WFP and ACF warehouses. At least six humanitarian organizations reported damage or looting. Some looted goods were distributed among residents. At least 15 vehicles were stolen, including 4x4s, a car carrying medicine, and a large truck (vehicles belonging to MSF, ACF, local forces, and civilians). About six MSF and ACF vehicles were used to transport food products to the coastal areas of Mucojo and Quiterajo. The Islamic State claimed the clash.

column25: On 6 March 2024, Islamist militia killed six civilians, including at least one farmer, in Pulo (Metuge, Cabo Delgado). Residents of Pulo, Nacuta, Ponto A, Chauli, Walopwana, and Muisse fled towards Pemba and Metuge. The Islamic State claimed the attack and burning of a 'Christian' school and 29 houses. Captives were released by the militia some hours after the attack.

column25: On 3 March 2024, Islamist militia killed at least seven police officers (disputing reports, ranging between seven and nine) at a police outpost in Quirimba Island (Ibo, Cabo Delgado), which resulted in much of the population and the police fleeing into the bush. After controlling the island, they looted and killed several oxen on the Gessner plantation, a cow, and shared the meat with the locals. Authorities decreed a curfew starting at 8 pm, and government officials were evacuated by helicopter to Pemba. The Islamic State claimed the attack and the killing of nine soldiers, two drowned trying to flee, five captured and later killed.

column25: On 9 February 2024, more than 150 Islamist militia clashed with Mozambican forces in Mucojo (Macomia, Cabo Delgado), following the recent occupation of the village by Mozambican forces. At least 20 soldiers were killed (between 20 and 25). Islamist militia seized food and forced civilians to carry food to an area further north. The Islamic State claimed the killing of 25 people, including 23 soldiers (one beheaded after hours of interrogation), a member in the local force and a civilian. At least two people were beheaded. Weapons were seized. A military helicopter appeared during the clash but withdrew when it came under fire.

column23: AIM; Carta de Mocambique; Centro de Integridade Publica (CIP); Lusa; Miramar; Mozambique Bulletin Subscribe; Noticias; O Pais; VOA; Zitamar
column25: Elections/referendum: On 10 December 2023, people voted for municipal elections for a second time in Nacala Porto, Marromeu, Milange and Gurue, coded to Gurue (Gurue, Zambezia) as elections were annulled due to irregularities in these four municipalities. Electoral authorities issued preliminary results giving victory to Frelimo in all four towns (90% Nacala Porto, 55.2% Marromeu, unknown Milange, 62.17% in Gurue). Repeat elections were considered fraudulent again, due to the following practices: ballot box stuffing; arbitrary detentions of candidate delegates and police violence; people being prevented from voting by members of polling stations; falsified notice and minutes. The Constitutional Council (CC) rejected Renamo's appeal for the annulment of the municipal vote in Marromeu. The Gurue District Judicial Court alleged electoral fraud in the rerun of the vote in Gurue but denied New Democracy's appeal for the annulment of the municipal vote in Gurue.

Other: On 10 December 2023, police officers closed the main roads of Milange (Milange, Zambezia) blocking voters from going to the three polling stations that were subject to repeat elections. October elections were annulled due to irregularities and repeated in Gurue, Marromeu, Pebane and Nacala Porto.

The officers hit the man on the back of his neck with a riffle butt. The man was taken to a hospital.

column25: On 6 December 2023, members of the Rapid Intervention Unit and of the Special Operations Group invaded Renamo premises and fired live bullets and tear gas against Renamo members and supporters in Nampula (Nampula, Nampula). The incident happened after two suspected police agents were taken to the party premises by Renamo supporters accused of spying their demonstration (coded separately). One was identified as a police agent and other as a member of the Special Operations Group of the police after interrogation by the group. Some residents, including children, felt sick because of the tear gas. More than 50 Renamo members and supporters were detained by the forces. Police apprehended computers, cell phones and printers.

On 6 December 2023, Renamo supporters marched in Nampula (Nampula, Nampula) against the October election results, which gave majority of municipalities win to Frelimo. Since the election, the group claims elections in several municipalities were fraudulent; in November the Constitutional Council proclaimed Frelimo the winner of the local elections in 56 municipalities, instead of 64 previously announced by the National Elections Council, scheduling a revote in 4 municipalities on 10 December. Protesters became aware of the presence of two undercover police officers and took them to Renamo premises for interrogation, leading to the assault of Renamo premises by special police forces (coded separately).

Since the election, the group claims elections in several municipalities were fraudulent; in November the Constitutional Council proclaimed Frelimo the winner of the local elections in 56 municipalities, instead of 64 previously announced by the National Elections Council, scheduling a revote in 4 municipalities on 10 December. Police intervened with tear gas and arrested 13 people. At least three people were injured, two had minor injuries and were discharged.

column25: On 5 December 2023, Renamo supporters gathered in demonstration outside the Murrupelane primary school in Nacala Porto (Nacala, Nampula). column25: On 16 November 2023, Renamo supporters protested in Angoche (Angoche, Nampula) against the announcement from the National Elections Council confirming that Frelimo won 64 out of 65 municipalities after local elections on 11 October. The group held a coffin covered with a Frelimo cloth. The police seized the coffin and opened fire after demonstrators demanded the coffin back. Eight people were shot. One woman was killed and at least six people were seriously injured. Two people went to a hospital. Officers also used tear gas. Five people were detained. The Interior Minister claimed that the police fired live ammunition to prevent Renamo members attacking a police station with machetes, sticks and stones.

column25: On 27 October 2023, thousands Renamo supporters blocked main avenues with piles of thrash and burning tires and threw stones during a demonstration in Maputo (Maputo City, Maputo) against the announcement from the National Elections Council confirming that Frelimo won 64 out of 65 municipalities after local elections on 11 October. Riot police and plainclothes officers intervened with several tear gas shots and AK-47 gunfire into the air. 23 people were arrested. 10 people were injured. The Interior Minister claimed that 236 people were detained for involvement in acts of violence during demonstrations in Nampula, Zambezia, Maputo, Niassa, Sofala and Tete and that there were 130 demonstrations throughout the country, of which 25 were violent. He also claimed that the police seized 59 homemade explosive devices, 55 in Maputo and 4 in Nampula (coded separately). Similar demonstrations were held in other locations (coded separately).

column25: On 27 October 2023, Renamo supporters barricaded roads with burning tires, threw stones and sticks at shops and vandalized vehicles during a demonstration in Nampula (Nampula, Nampula) against the announcement from the National Elections Council confirming that Frelimo won 64 out of 65 municipalities after local elections on 11 October. The railway line was blocked. An armored vehicle was used to spray water against no specific targets. Police officers intervened with live bullets. At least three people died (disputing reports ranging between 3 and 4), including a 14-year-old child, a market seller and one police officer who died from his injuries at Nampula Central Hospital. Several people were injured, including nine civilians with gunshots. 9 police officers were injured in Nampula and Nacala. One member of the Rapid Intervention Unit had his forearm amputated, hit by a homemade bomb. The Minister of Interior claimed that the police seized 59 homemade explosive devices, 4 in Nampula and 55 in Maputo (coded separately). 60 people were arrested. Similar demonstrations were held in other locations (coded separately).

column23: AIM; BBC News; Carta de Mocambique; O Pais
column25: On 12 October 2023, Renamo supporters staged a protest claiming fraud in the elections in Chiure (Chiure, Cabo Delgado). The police fired live bullets and at least one person was killed, while two other people were injured, including 12 years old. In a statement, the Frelimo Central Committee claimed four people were killed in the incident. The spokesperson for the PRM provincial command in Pemba denied that the two minors were Renamo supporters. Ten Renamo members were arrested.

column23: Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Centro de Integridade Publica (CIP); GardaWorld; Lusa; Mozambique Bulletin Subscribe
column25: Elections/referendum: On 11 October 2023, people voted for municipal elections in Mozambique, coded to Maputo (Maputo City, Maputo). Elections were held on the country's 65 municipalities, including 12 new municipalities which voted for the first time. Frelimo won in 64 municipalities and MDM won in Beira. Of the 65 municipalities, at least two canceled the ballot due to alleged irregularities in the province of Niassa (coded separately) and at least two districts in Maputo (coded separately) canceled the vote. Paralel counts conducted by Consorcio Eleitoral Mais showed that Renamo won in Maputo, Matola, Quelimane and Nampula. Renamo proved that ballot boxes were stuffed in Quelimane, according to the decision of the Constitutional Council (CC). Renamo cited 39 polling stations that were subject to ballot box stuffing. In Marromeu parallel count in 28 polling stations showed that 11 of that group had ballot box stuffing. More Integrity observers showed that Renamo won in Chiure. The Constitutional Council ruled that if only part of a gross fraud is appealed, the fraud can be ignored. Constitutional Council confirmed fraud in the elections and declared that Renamo won in Chiure, Quelimane, Alto Molocue and Vilankulo.

column23: AIM; Amaq; Cabo Ligado; Carta de Mocambique; Integrity Magazine; Twitter; Zitamar
column25: On 15 April 2023, Mozambican military forces, local forces and SADC clashed with Islamist Militia in Miangalewa (Muidumbe, Cabo Delgado). A Rwandan helicopter intervened (no details about air attacks). At least one local force was killed and up to four were wounded. 500 civilians fled the area due to the attacks. The militia set fire to a broken down truck and the Islamic state claimed they seized a mortar, a medium machine gun, and other weapons and ammunition. The Islamic State claimed the attack as an ambush on the road to Miangalewa and the killing of one SADC soldier.

On 29 March 2023, Renamo boycotted the Assembly of the Republic in Maputo (Maputo, Maputo City), protesting against the alteration of one electoral law, which states that the President of the Republic must fix the date of presidential and parliamentary elections 18 months in advance, now reduced to 15 months. Frelimo claimed that with the reduction of the deadline, conditions would be created to broaden the debate on whether or not the district elections will take place. Renamo shouted, waved placards and used plastic horns. MDM members left the assembly to express their boycott.

On 28 March 2023, workers (assumed miners) protested at the company offices at Montepuez Ruby Mining Limited (Montepuez, Cabo Delgado), demanding a pay rise and better working conditions. Protesters sang close to the company's offices preventing colleagues who did not adhere to the strike from working.

column25: On 18 March 2023, a group of people gathered in demonstration in Maputo (Maputo, Maputo City), Quelimane (coded separately, Chimoio (coded separately), Beira (coded separately), Nampula, (coded separately) and Xai-Xai (coded separately) to pay homage to a rapper who died recently. They were stopped by police officers, including members of the RIU, who intervened with dogs, tear gas, rubber bullets, bullets, and clubs. 22 people were arrested and 19 went to a hospital. Two men lost the sight of one eye hit by rubber bullets fired at close range. Disputing reports regarding number of arrests in total, from 36 to 108 being detained.

The Islamic State claimed the attack.

column25: On 5 June 2022, a group of Islamist militia attacked the village Nanduli in the district of Ancuabe (Ancuabe, Cabo Delgado). Dozens of houses were set on fire and people were kidnapped. At least one person died. There are conflicting reports, with sources claiming that two civilians were killed, including a woman who was beheaded and the guard of a farm which belongs to a Frelimo's politician, while other source reports that at least seven people were killed. Around 2500 people fled the area. One woman who was captured was later released. The Islamic State claimed the attack on a 'Christian village' and that one person was killed, beheaded.

On 8 March 2022, citizens rioted after the discovery of the body of a man in a warehouse. The victim had been imprisoned in the warehouse by his manager after being suspected of theft. The victim died of asphyxiation after three days of imprisonment. The manager was arrested but was released a few days later. The rioters burned tires and barricaded roads in the main village of Papatane (Mabote, Inhambane). Thirteen demonstrators were arrested.

On 8 March 2022, residents of Coromana staged a demonstration, demanding the release of four citizens who had been arrested the day before in a demonstration against the local government's decision to discontinue the longstanding use of Malawian currency (the kwacha) in commercial transactions. The demonstration took place in Coromana, Molumbo in Milange (Milange, Zambezia). Police stations, private vehicles, and the house of the Chief of Police were vandalized, fires were lit and barricades were constructed. A commission of PRM (police), border guards, and UIR (Rapid Intervention Unit) officers responded by firing at demonstrators (assumed with rubber bullets). Two citizens were killed, and one was wounded.

column25: Other: On 17 February 2022, a group of unidentified armed men in two vehicles shot at the main access gate and at the electrical transformer of a maximum security jail in Maputo (Maputo, Maputo City) and threw a smoke grenade to cover their identities. The former president of Mozambique was in the jail to testify, and the group hit the electrical transformer to sabotage the trial and the live transmission of the court hearing. The former president was head of the government that issued the guarantees that allowed the Mozambican Tuna Company (Ematum), Proindicus and Mozambique Asset Management (MAM) to borrow money from foreign banks. The group fled after prison guards responded to the attack.

column25: Displacement: Around 28 December 2021 (as reported), about 3,803 refugees were camping in Mecula (Mecula, Niassa) after they left their houses in villages near Mecula [Naulala 2, Chitande, Mecula, Muchenga and Macalange] throughout the month due to recent attacks perpetrated by members of an Islamist militia in November and December 2021. Mecula received refugees from 25 November 2021 to 11 January 2022.

On 27 December 2021, a group of about 20 members of an Islamist militia attacked the village of Alassima near Mecula (Mecula, Niassa). Five people were killed. Houses were burned and seven men and 4 women were kidnapped. The women were released and instructed to inform the Mozambican forces that the Islamist militia would attack the village soon.

column25: On 22 December 2021, a group of Islamist militia killed five people including a Special Reserve Inspector in an attack in Naulala in the district of Mecula (Mecula, Niassa). Several people were kidnapped and two women were released before the militia left the village. Two vehicles, including a police truck, were burned as the Islamist militia left the village. The Islamic State claimed the attack and that 6 Mozambican soldiers were killed. Fatalities coded as 5.

column25: On 11 October 2021, Mozambican forces clashed with members of the Renamo Military Junta in the bushes of Djovo in the district of Cheringoma (Cheringoma, Sofala). The leader of the Military Junta and his closest follower were killed. Three AKM-type weapons, 96 AKM ammunition and a pistol were confiscated during the confrontation. Some sources report no traces of blood on the bodies of the victims, suspecting they were poisoned.

On 7 October 2021, pro-government militia captured and summarily executed four people presumably members of an Islamist militia in Muatide (Muidumbe, Cabo Delgado) after the group found uniforms from the Mozambican military in the victims' bags.

Around 7 October 2021 (between 6 - 8 October), Mozambican authorities captured seven boats off the coast of Mocimboa Da Praia (Mocimboa Da Praia, Cabo Delgado), arresting an unknown number of crew and passengers. The boats were carrying supplies from Pemba to Palma. The arrest was likely due to suspected links between those on the boats and Islamist militia.

On 6 October 2021, Mozambican and Rwandan forces ambushed members of an Islamist militia in Limala (Mocimboa da Praia, Cabo Delgado) and killed two militants, including a leader of the group, who reportedly ordered a massacre that killed over 50 people in Xitati (Muidumbe) in 2019.
